itemDescription: barrister, farmer, and British Conservative Party politician (1912-2007)

wikipedia_page.main: John Edward Bernard Hill (13 November 1912 – 6 December 2007) was a British barrister, farmer and Conservative politician who served as Member of Parliament (MP) for South Norfolk for 19 years, from 1955 to 1974. He was also one of the UK's first MEPs, serving from 1973 to 1974.

He was subsequently convicted on all seven counts and was sentenced at the Old Bailey to seven years imprisonment."Sentence on M.P.", The Times, 1 December 1954, p. 8. See also "Certified copies of the indictment, conviction and sentence of the Court in the case of the Queen against Peter Arthur David Baker", House of Commons Paper 11 of session 1954–55. Immediately on his imprisonment at HM Prison Wormwood Scrubs, Baker was given permission by the Prison Governor to write to the Speaker of the House of Commons.In "Time Out of Life", pp. 31–32, Baker claims he had to write a second time because the Wormwood Scrubs authorities always tore up the first letter any prisoner sent to an MP. Explaining that he had discovered he was "unable to vacate my seat in any way while the matter was sub judice", he stated that he was not going to appeal and therefore "you can now dispossess me of my seat without delay".Publisher's note, "My Testament", p. 288. The Leader of the House of Commons Harry Crookshank then put down a motion "That Mr. Peter Arthur David Baker be expelled this House" which was agreed without a division on 16 December 1954.Hansard, HC 5ser vol 535 col 1986. In the subsequent by-election in January 1955, South Norfolk elected Conservative John Hill as its new MP.

** John Hill, politician (born 1912)
* 13 November – John Hill, politician (died 2007)

The result was a narrow win for the Conservative candidate John Hill, with a majority of only 865 votes (2.9%) over his sole opponent, the Labour candidate J. M. Stewart. At the general election in May 1955, Hill again faced Stewart, and on a much higher turnout held the seat with a majority of 1,475 (4.1%).Richard Kimber's political science resources: UK General Election results May 1955  He remained South Norfolk's MP until his retirement from Parliament at the February 1974 general election.

Sotherton Hall is a grade II listed Tudor timber framed farmhouse or Hall house with a shaped brick gable end, set by a listed 17th/18th century timber framed and weatherboarded barn, in a small park towards the North of the parish  mentioned by Nikolaus Pevsner. It belonged to the Earls of Stradbroke, as part of the Henham Park estate, until 1951 when it became part of the Blyford Estate of John Hill.https://portal.uea.ac.uk/documents/6207125/6460911/Hill%2BPapers%2Blisting.pdf/4ede29f5-95b1-4499-a809-d05b5f48bda6
